bug.short_desc: Incorrect null analysis error reporting on type parameters

long_desc.thetext:
Created attachment 242949 Example project with bug as described
On Eclipse Luna M7, Build ID 20140508-1440, Java 1.8.0_05. Null analysis appears to ignore @NonNullByDefault in package-info.java, so type parameters in interfaces cause an error, stating "Null constraint mismatch: The type '@NonNull <subtype>' is not a valid substitute for the type parameter 'T' which is constrained as '@Nullable'". In addition, while an error might be shown in the editor, the null error does not prevent the program from launching.
Attached is an example project. I experienced an error in ExpressionNode.

At a cursory look two things look fishy:
- error detected only by reconciler not by the compiler/builder
- by way of the default (via constant DefaultLocation.TYPE_BOUND), this: CopyableNode<T extends ExtendedNode> should indeed be interpreted as CopyableNode<T extends @NonNull ExtendedNode>
The bug can be avoided, e.g., by including the TYPE_PARAMETER constant to the @NonNullByDefault (which I don't recommend, though).
Tentatively pulling into 4.4 - no promise yet.

Created attachment 243366 draft patch
Here's a draft of the patch I have in mind. Still need to do more testing.
Explanation:
The main change is in TypeReference, where previously we compared concrete type arguments against type variables just by an exact match of the toplevel null-tagBits. This fails to discriminate *where* exactly the null annotation is attached. Hence the confusion that leads to the bogus error.
Corrected by using the more sophisticated infrastructure from NullAnnotationMatching.analyse (wasn't available when I initially wrote the check in TypeReference). I still need to investigate if the semantics needs fine tuning for this use-case as we are not doing a plain isCompatibleWith-check, but a form of bound check. But I'm convinced that for type details like nested type arguments the checks are indeed the same as for compatibility checks.
Part 2 of the change relates again to processing order, because the new checks need fully resolved bindings, and when invoked during connectTypeHierarchy() this information may still be incomplete. Luckily, just recently we analysed what is done for regular bound check: deferring via ClassScope.deferredBoundChecks. Given that the checks discussed here are indeed a form of bound check, it is only natural to include them in the same structure: - if PSTR.internalResolveType has !checkBounds we skip the null checks on type arguments - *during* PSTR.checkBounds we do check the deferred null constraints, too
TODO: integrate the same also into PSTR.

Created attachment 243371 proposed patch - part 1
During extended testing I found that a bit more fine tuning is needed. For easier reviewing (and easier explaining :) ) I'm splitting the patch into parts for the individual steps of changes.
This part only contains the better integration of TypeReference.checkNullConstraints() into the general compile phases, which is needed to avoid issues of process order for the upcoming main part of the patch:
When resolving a parameterized type reference (single or qualified) we now respect the checkBounds flag to decide whether to work now or wait for deferred bound checking. For that sake of the latter, let checkBounds() call checkNullConstraints(), too.
With this, the control structure for null constraint checking for type arguments is well in line with bound checking.
That's all in this step :)

Created attachment 243372 proposed patch - part 2
We will be reporting errors to signal incompatibilities like this:
interface I <E extends List<@NonNull Object>> { ... }
I<List<@Nullable String>>
Previously we said
964 = Null constraint mismatch: The type ''{2}'' is not a valid substitute for the type parameter ''{0}'' which is constrained as ''@{1}''
rendering as
Null constraint mismatch: The type 'List<@Nullable String>' is not a valid substitute for the type parameter 'E' which is constrained as '@Nullable'.
The last segment is problematic, because we will be flagging some constraints that may not affect the type variable itself but details of its bound.
So I changed the message to
Null constraint mismatch: The type 'List<@Nullable String>' is not a valid substitute for the type parameter 'E extends List<@NonNull Object>'.
This is the best I can currently do to also cover complex cases. Some existing tests needed adjusting for this. A few messages actually render a bit funny, because annotations are duplicated on the type variable *and* its bound. I checked that none of these messages are outright wrong. Polish can well be postponed IMHO (e.g., avoid printing implicit bounds etc.).
Still not much code changed :)

Created attachment 243373 proposed patch - part 3
Just a little refactoring to prepare for more modes of checking in NullAnnotationMatching.analyse(..)
No semantic change in this patch (old boolean 'strict' corresponds to new enum constant 'OVERRIDE').

Created attachment 243374 proposed patch - part 4
This final step brings the actual payload:
In TypeReference we call NAM.analyse(...CheckMode.BOUND_CHECK) rather than the over-simplistic direct comparison of just one level of tag bits we had so far.
Inside analyse() some fine tuning is applied, based on the CheckMode:
- when doing bound checking against a type variable, additionally check against all its upper bounds (and be sure not to loose the previous 'severity' but consistently use Math.max()).
- but don't apply the pessimistic checks introduced in bug 430150: those rules handle the case of 'free type variables', where we must assume the worst in both directions. By contrast during bound check we *have* the concrete type arguments, and an unconstrained type variable actually means either instantiation - @NonNull or @Nullable - is OK (this is the change inside requiredNullTagBits()).
That's all, and instead of a strawman implementation, we have some serious checking of null constraints on type arguments vs. parameters. One test has a fixme to remind me that this still isn't complete, but I think this is the best we can do for Luna.
BTW, thanks to Alex for bringing this to my attention!

Final comments for review:
- tests are green.
- the main new entry is TypeReference.checkNullConstraints(Scope, TypeBinding[], int) which has two callers, both of which check the null annotation option prior to calling.
Ergo: with null annotations disabled none of the code changes should make a difference -- just for fail-safe :)

(In reply to Stephan Herrmann from comment #8) > Ergo: with null annotations disabled none of the code changes should make > a difference -- just for fail-safe :)
Thanks, I have confirmed that too. Otherwise, I was bit worried about the size of the size of the patch, although most could be attributed to the test changes and refactoring.
+1 for patch; thanks Stephan for the detailed explanation

Thanks.
Released for 4.4 RC2 in parts as given above:
- integrate into phase of bound checking: http://git.eclipse.org/c/jdt/eclipse.jdt.core.git/commit/?id=037cfa6bf481cd6ec3ad222bceff2d82fb8a8179
- adjust error message: http://git.eclipse.org/c/jdt/eclipse.jdt.core.git/commit/?id=30d1d48bfa7e296fbeab8a3626c28e1130f44500
- refactoring to prepare for more check modes: http://git.eclipse.org/c/jdt/eclipse.jdt.core.git/commit/?id=8f838ccefdcacadaac662cb88a80fdb1a3657843
- the payload: http://git.eclipse.org/c/jdt/eclipse.jdt.core.git/commit/?id=658041315da1052ce94c7e1b37be530cbc4e1f1d

Verified for 4.4 RC2 with build I20140524-1500
For records, while experimenting I noticed that the type in the compiler error would toggle between '@Nullable S extends Object' and '@Nullable S' depending on reconcile or a full build.

attachment.desc: Example project with bug as described
